P-D2: A professor declined to give me a rotation opportunity based on my perceived disability status -- the professor guessed that I have a certain disability and felt that I would be less productive/more difficult to mentor because of it. This only happened once.
P-D5: I now happen to work closely with this professor and I am afraid of retaliation if I report the instance -- the professor could easily guess who submitted the report.

FreeRep Com:
More zoom interactions with peers 
Safe spaces to express fears of the pandemic 
Virtual Check Ins

P-M2: Frequently being put down for being less “intelligent” than the individual. While I don’t believe it, it wears on you. It’s very frequent.
P-M4: Nothing was done. It’s been 2 years.
OtherFR: What really can be done??? Nothing. Once a PI has tenure. They are invincible. They can do whatever they want and if we (as graduate students) say anything nothing is done. If a student is toxic. What can the PI do? Nothing. What, are they going to fire them? As if.
Actions: Sexism is very real. It’s frequent and unacceptable.

P-D2:
Favoritism/bias of more privileged graduate students for lab positions, even when they were less experienced (and taking UC start up money and supporting an out-of-state, less experienced graduate student).  Experienced out right discrimination in the lab I chose to join.  Being targeted by the PI and embarassed in every lab meeting.  While I was busy gathering data for 10 months, another graduate student from neuroscience wasn't collecting any data and being given a pass, while I was continually ridiculed.  Finally, the post-doc in that lab told me that he and the PI talk a lot about me, then proceeded to tell me I should just 'get over talking about or caring  about LGBTQIA+ issues in academia''.  Which all seems like a systemic harrassment and bias towards me.  

In addition to that, I have witnessed/experienced multiple unethical behaviors/comments from multiple Professors.  One lab, the PI was proselytizing to all the lab members about religion (one of the lab members was openly playing a religious sermon in the lab, too).  For marginalized people, religion is/can be a trigger because many have been abused by religious zealotry.  Besides, this is a public institutution and separation of state and church should be upheld.  I can provide a list of all the unethical, illegal instances that I've witnessed at UC Davis, of which there a way too many.  Even though I'm doing well now with my new PI, UC Davis to date is the most institutionally unethical and unaccountable organization I've ever been associated with.   Maybe that is unavoidable because that is what 'academia' has/is historically been - yet that's not a good excuse.
P-D4: I informed multiple other Professors about the implicit/institutionalized bias that was preventing me from advancing as a healthy graduate student.
P-B4: see previous comments.  By the way, the question asking 'year of program', combined with the person's comments, is in no way an 'anonymous' survey.  You all probably know who I am just by comments and year of program.  This survey is NOT ANONYMOUS.
Actions: Yes, the faculty should change the by-laws to require diversity, equity training for all BMCDB/CBS trainers.  Faculty will also need to form a committee to respond more directly and decisively when there are cases of discrimination/bias/microaggressions.  From my experience with my experiences with other universities/colleges that have better systems of blocking discrimination from faculty, etcetera, the changes have all been concretized by the faculty, not the students.  Putting the burned on to students is not fair and will not change anything.  The faculty have the leverage to make genuine change.  This has to happen from the faculty!  Otherwise, this could all just be performative allyship, and nothing more.
FreeRep Com: Required ethnic studies seminars for all incoming cohorts.

Actions: Include conversations and talks as a REQUIRED course or seminar in a REGULAR (once a month or so) basis which MUST be attended by BOTH students and PIs.

P-B2: During rotations some PIs seemed to be favoring US citizens over the international students since international students are not eligible to apply for any federal funding like NIH or NSF fellowships/training grants.
P-B5: There was no way to prove that since the PIs were just saying that the students they were accepting into their labs, who were US citizens, were better fits.
P-M2: During the rotation talks, one of the faculty who was evaluating the talks was being extremely critical about small grammatical errors that any international student had, and making comments like international students should be getting extra help even though most of these students had lived in the US for over 5 years and obtained college degrees from US institutions; therefore having superb English language qualifications. The same faculty was also making remarks about how hard it was for them to understand the talk due to "the way" international students were speaking. All these remarks and comments were making me and all the other international students in my cohort very uncomfortable and self-conscious when we needed to give a talk in front of this certain faculty member.
P-M5: I did not know this could be reported. I also believe that if we were to report this person it wouldn't have changed anything really since it is very clear that this faculty member has a certain level of bias towards international students who are not native English speakers.

Actions:
Ensuring there is a reliable and safe way to report instances and hold faculty accountable. It should also be possible to remove faculty that abuse students,
are the subject of reported incidents etc. from BMCDB.

OtherFR: I had a very awkward last rotation where the PI & project scientist did most of my project for me and didn't want to teach me their techniques. I wasn't planning on joining the lab (and they knew that) but they took my idea for a collaborative project and worked on it without me. I don't think they are planning on publishing it, but the rotation ended on poor terms and did not keep in touch.
FreeRep Com: Virtual seminars! Bring back the joint molecular biology seminars.

P-M2: Few times, faculty cycling through all the names of the other asian people in my cohort before reaching my name.
P-M5: Didn't feel like it warranted report.

OtherFR: Often times when an issue with a faculty member is brought to the attention of another faculty member, the response is that there isn't much that can be done and that their hands are tied, which is disappointing.

FreeRep Com: A potential idea could be playing video games together. I'm not sure how much interest there would be though.

P-B5: I thought people might think that I am silly for bringing up such issues

P-B2: My PI consistently gave credit for my work to the older, more senior, male post doctoral student.
P-B5: I directly addressed this issue with my PI himself

P-M2: Single time in a conversation with a BMCDB faculty (I did not have another conversation with them), I am repeatedly told that my teaching experience in other countries will not be comparable to the experience in the US.
P-M5: I told the faculty that what they are telling me is not 'okay'. Microaggressions are in that gray area, many people do not even think that such behaviors inappropriate or discriminatory in some cases, so I did not attempt to report this incident.

OtherFR: I think BMCDB has been an excellent place for grad students the entire time I've been in grad school. I have witnessed hiccups in the system but as a whole the grad group does it's best to support all students equally.

P-D2:
My UCD email is a condensed version of my cultural name. My alternate email is my western name. When emailing professors for a first meeting (as in scheduling rotations or short meetings for advice on experiments within their specialties), guess which one garners responses? 
The effect is somewhat mitigated after a first conversation when there is at least a memory of me, but I am aware that my colleagues have had many more faculty invested in their success than I have had. Whether this is simply a mismatch of cultural norms or active discrimination is not the point - there are simply more opportunities for help if one looks or speaks a certain way. 
For more specificity, here are some examples.
Example 1: There was an instance where my PI and I accompanied a safety inspector's review of student signatures on documents. Upon noticing that I shared a last name with a lab member, she remarked "Oh! Are you two related? You have the same last name!" My PI, seeing me visibly perturbed, responds with a come-on-let-it-go face, "Well, it's not a common name." My surname is in fact a very common name. This would have been a prime opportunity for him to cure her of the ignorance by saying "Well it's a common name in X culture", because he had two students of the same ethnicity with the same name, but obviously not related. The question then becomes, "well why didn't you say anything?" to which I would respond that I simply should not have to in a mentor-mentee relationship. 
Example 2: 
My PI is for some reason very annoyed at not knowing that it is one of his student's birthdays and finds out on the day of. After one such occurrence, he proceeded to jokingly ask the only female student in the lab, "You're supposed to keep track of these things." 
Example 3: 
Just prior to the pandemic, a Chinese international student in the lab began wearing a mask. In a private meeting with me, my PI expressed hesitation in asking whether he had contracted COVID, because he "sees a lot of them wearing masks anyway."
P-D5:
How could I have reported these events and not expected repercussions only towards myself? The power dynamic is so incredibly vast. The responsibility cannot be on the graduate student in the current system. Our very basic capability to live and eat is based on our PI's opinion of what we can provide to them. Persistent aversion to conflict on the part of faculty members completely destroys opportunities for open discussion and there is no incentive for that to change. For faculty, there are simply no meaningful repercussions, even in cases with egregious offense. 
Also, to whom would one even report? It took a very high-visibility national movement to spawn a BMCDB exploratory committee, emphasis on exploratory. From early Zoom meetings, it feels as if the onus is put back on the graduate students. The conversation boils down to "We can't institute change because the rules say no, but you students go ahead and push for change because this is really your problem."
